head.supplied: Australian Fungi ¶ Unless otherwise noted, each name in the list has a✓to its left.Note that these fungi had not necessarily been sent to Cooke by M. Some bear numbers, but there is no key to them pro...

div.p: RB MSS M86B, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

The list is one of a number sent by Cookethat arenowin the library of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne. Australian Fungi
Unless otherwise noted, each name in the list has a ✓ to its left.Note that these fungi had not necessarily been sent to Cooke by M. Some bear numbers, but there is no key to them provided.

Fr

Boletus (subtomentosus Fr ?)
FNI gives Linnaeus as the author, not Fries.There is no ✓ against this name.

cell.p:
Ag.
Agaricus.
(Crepidotus)pactolus Cke
Non-standard abbreviation for Cooke;Mlisted'[Agaricus] pactolus, Cooke (Crepidotus)'in B85.10.04without description, and no formal publication has been found (FNI and Index fungorum, accessed 4 April 2021).

Agaricus. FNI gives Bulliard as the author, not Fries.There is no ✓ against this name.
(Amanita) vaginatus Fr. Prox.

border: none; padding-top: 0in; padding-left: 0.075in; padding-bottom: 0in; padding-right: 0.075in;
cell.p:
Port Phillip (French)
Vic.It is not known whether the collector isCharles FrenchSnrorhis sonCharles H. French.MEL has fungi,including some dated before 1885,collected by each. The specimen of Geoglossum
m uelleri attributed to the elder French (MEL 2069157) is dated to 1887 (AVH, accessed 8 November 2023).

cell.p:
Hymenochaete purpurea C & M
Cooke & Morgan.

cell.p:
Moona N E
Probably 'Moona Plains' a grazing property near Walcha,New Englnd(NSW), from where Alexander Crawford sent specimens to M;see,for example,A. Crawford to M, 1884(in this edition as 84-00-00f).

NowLorne, Vic;probablyAmy Beal, who is known to have collected algae for M there(see J. Agardh to M, 30 April 1885).

FNI give the author of the combination as 'Kunze ex FR.) Fr.'.

div.p:
The remaining text is at the bottom of the second page of the sheet.
My dear Baron

I have received 2 or 3 letters from you to which I have not replied
Letters not found.
(I) Because postage is so heavy until your Government will adopt Postal Cards (2) Because I had but little to say.

As far as I can I will save you specimens of Australian Fungi, but hitherto duplicates were handed over to Kew. I have already a number laid aside for you. My "Illustrations" occupy an immense time as I do not employ an artist at all but draw all myself and color the patterns.
Cooke (1881-91).
This with the revision of all
Pyrenomycetes
Cooke published his 'Synopsis Pyrenomycetum' across several issues of Grevillea, commencing with Cooke (1884) and concluding with Cooke (1891). The articles were reprinted in Cooke (1886-91).
and a proposed Monograph of
Polyporus
The proposed monograph was not published but Cooke issued in seven parts his 'preliminary lists, imperfect though they may be, in order to indicate the arrangement we have decided to adopt' (Cooke (1885), p. 80), with the last issued as Cooke (1886-7), pp. 50-60.
are about sufficient work for 2 or 3 men. Excuse this short note — as you want the above list.
